security_audit.summary: This skill provides SAST security scanning documentation and tooling using Semgrep. All 338 flagged patterns are false positives - they are intentional educational examples showing vulnerable code patterns in documentation, Semgrep rule templates designed to detect those patterns, and standard CI/CD shell commands. No actual malicious code or security risks exist.

content.user_title: Scan Code for Security Vulnerabilities with Semgrep
content.value_statement: Security vulnerabilities in code can lead to data breaches and system compromise. This skill provides comprehensive SAST scanning with Semgrep, mapping findings to OWASP Top 10 and CWE standards for prioritized remediation.
actual_capabilities: Run Semgrep scans with curated security rulesets
Map findings to OWASP Top 10 2021 and CWE categories
Generate CI/CD pipeline configurations for GitHub Actions and GitLab
Create custom Semgrep rules for organization-specific patterns
Provide remediation guidance for common vulnerability types
Scan 30+ programming languages including Python, JavaScript, Java, and Go
limitations: Semgrep must be installed locally or in CI environment
Cannot detect runtime vulnerabilities or business logic flaws
Custom rules require understanding of Semgrep pattern syntax
False positives may require manual triage for context-specific code

output_examples.input: Scan my Python Flask application for security issues
output: Found 3 HIGH severity findings in your Flask application
SQL Injection detected in app/models.py line 45 - using f-string in cursor.execute()
XSS vulnerability in templates/user.html line 12 - unescaped user input
Debug mode enabled in app.py line 8 - exposes sensitive information
Remediation: Use parameterized queries, enable auto-escaping, disable debug in production

output_examples.input: Help me understand the OWASP Top 10 coverage of my scan
output: Your scan covers 8 of 10 OWASP categories
A03 Injection: 5 findings (SQL injection, command injection)
A07 Auth Failures: 2 findings (weak password hashing with MD5)
No findings for: A04 Insecure Design, A06 Vulnerable Components

best_practices: Start with HIGH and CRITICAL severity findings before addressing MEDIUM and LOW
Establish a baseline scan and track metrics over time to measure improvement
Combine SAST with DAST and dependency scanning for defense in depth
anti_patterns: Do not suppress findings with nosemgrep comments without documented justification
Do not run comprehensive rulesets on every commit as this slows CI pipelines
Do not rely solely on automated scanning without manual code review for critical systems

faq.question: What languages does Semgrep support?
faq.answer: Semgrep supports 30+ languages including Python, JavaScript, TypeScript, Java, Go, Ruby, PHP, C, C++, Rust, Kotlin, Swift, Terraform, and Dockerfile.

faq.question: How do I reduce false positives?
faq.answer: Use targeted rulesets, create .semgrepignore files, tune severity thresholds, and add nosemgrep comments with justification for confirmed false positives.

faq.question: Can I scan only changed files in pull requests?
faq.answer: Yes. Use the --baseline-commit flag to scan only files changed since the base branch, reducing scan time and focusing on new code.

faq.question: How do I map findings to compliance frameworks?
faq.answer: Semgrep rules include CWE and OWASP metadata. Use the owasp_cwe_mapping.md reference to map findings to specific compliance requirements.

faq.question: What is the difference between p/security-audit and p/ci rulesets?
faq.answer: p/security-audit is comprehensive with more rules and potential false positives. p/ci is optimized for speed and low false positives in CI/CD pipelines.

faq.question: How do I create custom rules for my organization?
faq.answer: Use the rule_template.yaml as a starting point. Define patterns, messages, severity, and metadata. Test rules with semgrep --test against sample code.
